''[[Al Murray's Multiple Personality Disorder]]'' }} '''Laura Madalene Solon''' (born April 1979) is an [[English people|English]] screenwriter, comedian, actress, and winner of the 2005 [[Perrier Comedy Award]]. She was the second woman to win as a solo performer, after [[Jenny Eclair]] in 1995. ==Background== She was raised in [[Great Kimble]] near [[Aylesbury]]. She attended [[Downe House School]] followed by [[Worcester College, Oxford]] where she received a scholarship{{cite web|url=http://www.ox.ac.uk/gazette/1999-00/weekly/281099/coll.htm |title=Oxford University Gazette |publisher=Ox.ac.uk |date=28 October 1999 |accessdate=2010-04-24}} to read English and started writing and performing in the [[Oxford Revue]]. ==Career== Solon tried her hand at being a [[stand up comedy|stand up comedian]] but found character comedy suited her better.{{cite web|last=Lee |first=Veronica |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/arts/main.jhtml?xml=/arts/2005/08/31/btedsolon31.xml&sSheet=/living/2005/08/31/ixlivingtop.html |title='Perrier winner? I shouldn't have been on the list' |publisher=Telegraph |date=31 August 2005 |accessdate=2010-04-24}} In 2005 she won the [[Edinburgh Comedy Awards|Perrier Award]] for her one-woman [[Edinburgh Fringe]] show ''Kopfraper's Syndrome: One Man and His Incredible Mind''. Following this the [[BBC]] and [[Channel 4]] were keen to acquire her to produce material for them, and in April 2006 it was announced by the BBC that Solon had been signed to develop projects for them on Radio and TV.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2006/04_april/05/solon.shtml |title=Press Office - Laura Solon signs to |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=2010-04-24}} The first series of ''[[Laura Solon: Talking and Not Talking]]'', a sketch and character comedy series, ran on [[BBC Radio 4]] in January and February 2007. The second series ran in May and June 2008, and the third in November 2009.{{citation needed|date=June 2012}} She recorded a BBC [[Situation comedy|sitcom]] [[Television pilot|pilot]] from the creators of ''[[People Like Us (mockumentary)|People Like Us]]'', featuring ''[[Man Stroke Woman]]'''s [[Daisy Haggard]], called ''Great News''.{{cite web|url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2006/11/16/4705/comedy_news |title=Comedy news : News 2006 : Chortle : The UK Comedy Guide |publisher=Chortle |date=16 November 2006 |accessdate=2010-04-24}}[http://www.wiltshiretimes.co.uk/news/1064610.sitcom_makes_the_news/ Great News] She appeared in [[Harry Enfield]] and [[Paul Whitehouse]]'s [[sketch show]] ''[[Harry & Paul|Ruddy Hell! It's Harry and Paul]]'', broadcast from 2007 on [[BBC One]]. She was seen in a sketch show for [[ITV2]] ''Laura, Ben and Him'' (2008) with [[Marek Larwood]] and [[Ben Willbond]]. She was part of ''[[Al Murray's Multiple Personality Disorder]]'', shown on [[ITV1]].{{citation needed|date=June 2012}} Alongside [[Tony Hawks]] and [[Angus Deayton]] she appeared in the feature film ''[[Playing the Moldovans at Tennis]]'', which was recorded in 2010 and released in 2012. In the first half of 2010 she toured with ''Rabbit Faced Story Soup'', a play set in a publisher's office in which she played every character. It contained characters from her radio show, ''Talking and Not Talking'', including Carol Price, a divorcee children's author, and Gwynneth the inept call centre worker. New characters included Marcia, an American super publishing agent.{{citation needed|date=June 2012}} Her award-winning{{cite web|title=Accolade Competition Deadline: August 26, web|title=Work : Laura Solon|url=http://www.laurasolon.com/?page_id=5|accessdate=15 December 2011}} 2010 short film ''[[Tooty's Wedding]]'', which Solon co-wrote with [[Ben Willbond]], was screened as part of the [[2012 Sundance Film Festival]].{{cite web|last=Mann|first=Andrea|title=British Comedy Short 'Tooty's Wedding' Is Sundance-Bound (EXCLUSIVE CLIP)|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2011/12/15/tootys-wedding-sundance_n_1150288.html|work=Huffington Post UK|publisher=Aol (UK)|accessdate=15 December 2011|date=15 December 2011}} In 2011 Solon was one of the players in the BBC Two improvisational show ''[[Fast and Loose (TV series)|Fast and Loose]]'', hosted by [[Hugh Dennis]].{{cite web|url=http://www.comedy.co.uk/guide/tv/fast_and_loose/ |title=British Comedy Guide entry for Fast and Loose |publisher=British Comedy Guide |accessdate=2011-01-15}} ==''Kopfraper's Syndrome: One Man and His Incredible Mind''== The title is in fact a holdover from an entirely different show that Solon had planned to perform with a male partner{{Citation needed|date=December 2011}}. When the partner dropped out she rewrote the show in the three weeks leading up to the festival but retained the title in order not to negate the value of the advance publicity or confuse those who had already purchased tickets. Solon plays eight different characters in the show, which consists of sketches of varying lengths, including: *An [[Andrew Lloyd Webber]] fan *Caroline, an [[Australia]]n disabled housewife who is possessed by the ghost of [[Diana, Princess of Wales]] *Karen, a prize-winning beautician *Borgesia, a [[Poles|Polish]] story-teller *A wedding planner from [[Rotherham]] *A hunter who does not believe in [[zebra]]s *Katrina, a corporate high-flier with an irrational terror of the [[Chinese people|Chinese]] *A marketing assistant forced to dress as a bookworm As a Perrier award-winning show it secured a run in [[West End theatre|London's West End]], at the Soho Theatre, in November 2005. Solon also received [[pound sterling|£]]7,500 with the prize. ==Radio== *''[[Ed Reardon's Week]]'' - Lucy, in Series 3 *''[[Laura Solon: Talking and Not Talking]]'' (2007–09) *''[[Frank Skinner#Absolute Radio|Frank Skinner]] on [[Absolute Radio]]'' - Stand-in for Emily Dean (2009, 2011–12) *''[[Dave Gorman#Absolute Radio|Dave Gorman]] on [[Absolute Radio]]'' - Stand-in for [[Danielle Ward]] (2010) ==Television== *''[[Harry & Paul|Ruddy Hell! It's Harry and Paul]]'' (2007-) *''Laura, Ben and Him'' (2008) *''[[Al Murray's Multiple Personality Disorder]]'' (2009) *''[[Have I Got News for You]]'' (2010) *''[[Fast and Loose (TV series)|Fast and Loose]]'' (2011) ==Other drama== *''[[Orbis (Doctor Who Audio)]]'' - Selta ([[Big Finish Productions|Big Finish]]) (2009) ==Screenwriter== Solon has [[film adaptation|adapted]] [[comedy film]] [[screenplays]] for movies such as ''[[Office Christmas Party]]'', and ''[[In Her Shoes (film)|In Her Shoes]]'', and has had original screenplays (''Work It'' and ''Bodyguards'') optioned by [[Bluegrass Films]].{{cite news |url=https://deadline.com/2016/08/bodyguards-pitch-bluegrass-films-universal-laura-solon-1201802276/ |first=Anita |accessdate=27 June 2017 |date=15 August 2016 |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |title=Universal Pictures Picks Up ‘Bodyguards’ Pitch For Bluegrass Films |last=Busch}} Solon has also written episodes for season [[Hot in Cleveland (season 5)|5]] and [[Hot in Cleveland (season 6)|6]] of ''[[Hot in Cleveland]]''. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{IMDb name|id=2083678|name=Laura Solon}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Solon, Laura}} [[Category:1979 births]] [[Category:21st-century English actresses]] [[Category:21st-century British women writers]] [[Category:Alumni of Worcester College, Oxford]] [[Category:British women screenwriters]] [[Category:Date of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:English comedy writers]] [[Category:English television writers]] [[Category:English women comedians]] [[Category:English women writers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People educated at Downe House School]] [[Category:Writers from London]]
